title: Victor Haghani - The Last of the Tactical Allocators (S7E13)

rawLines.text: all right three two one Let's
Jam hello and welcome everyone I'm Cory
hoffstein and this is flirting with
models the podcast that pulls back the
curtain to discover the human factor
behind the quantitative
[Music]
strategy Cory hoffstein is the
co-founder and chief investment officer
of Newfound research due to Industry
regulations he will not discuss any of
Newfound research's funds on this
podcast all opinions expressed by
podcast participants are solely their
own opinion and do not reflect the
opinion of Newfound research this
podcast is for informational purposes
only and should not be relied upon as a
basis for investment decisions clients
of Newfound research May maintain
positions and securities discussed in
this podcast for more information visit
think new found.com
[Music]
my guest today is Victor hagani founder
of elm wealth Victor is in many ways one
of the last tactical asset allocators
standing after the 201 depends that
might be because Victor wouldn't
categorize himself as such rather he
sees his Dynamic index investing
approach not as a tactical alternative
to traditional static portfolios but
rather as the rational approach for
anyone starting from first principles
this conversation dances between Theory
and implementation Victor is just as
comfortable sharing his thoughts on
where Equity Market risk comes from as
he is defending payout adjusted Cape as
a metric for forecasting longrun returns
if you're passionate about asset
allocation you'll find lots to think
about in this one please enjoy my
conversation with Victor
[Music]
Hagan Victor welcome to the podcast
excited to have you here I actually
started reading all the many things
you've written over the years back when
you founded your firm back in 2011 if
I'm not mistaken and have been a
longtime Avid Reader of your work I
think it is some of the most lucid clear
writing on thinking about investing and
even just speculative Concepts so really
appreciate everything you put out in the
space and very excited to chat today
thank you for joining me thanks Corey
it's great to be on the podcast I love
your podcast I've enjoyed many different
sessions you've had with your guests
thank you so much so let's dive in you
started your career in the
1980s famously or infamously attached to
long-term Capital Management of which
there has been so much ink spilled
you've spoken about so I want to start
after that listeners if you want to get
Victor's take on that stuff this isn't
the episode we want to start in 2011
some three decades after you started
your career some 15 years or so after
long-term Capital Management take me to
that time what inspired you to launch
Elm what type of problem were you trying
to ultimately solve so we have to go
back a few years before 2011 but 2011 is
when I founded our wealth management
firm Elm wealth but after ltcm I woke up
and it wasn't a dream and I realized
that I needed to focus on managing my
family savings and up until that time I
had worked at an investment bank that
took a lot of my compensation and put it
into the stock of the company Solomon
and then at ltcm was pretty natural to
invest a lot of my savings in our fund
that we managed here it was you know
around 2000 2001 and I was like gez I've
got a figure out how to invest for my
family and it was kind of a shocking
realization to see that I had been
working in finance already for like 17
years working with some really Brilliant
Minds practitioners and academics and
yet I had never really thought much
about investing for myself all of my
focus was on Research to begin with and
then proprietary trading and my
situation was really typical too you
come out of college you go to Wall
Street and you get trained in everything
to do with Wall Street unless you're
going into a private wealth area which
Solomon didn't even have at the time you
don't really get trained at all in terms
of what to do with personal finance so
there I was and the natural thing to do
is I kind of looked around and saw what
my friends and people I respected were
doing and everybody was following this
concept of the Yale endowment model that
David Swenson was making so popular and
Yale's returns were making so attractive
there I was was you know I kind of knew
a bunch of people in private Equity the
hedge fund space Venture distress and I
just started to invest as if as though I
were the Yale endowment or something a
oneman Yale endowment and meanwhile I
was taking a sabatical from working my
kids were young and I wanted to spend
time with them and eventually maybe I
don't know exactly when after four or
five years I just kind of had this
realization that what I was doing just
made no sense at all it made no sense
from a life point of view it made no
sense from a risk and fee paying point
of view the straw that broke the camels
back on that approach to investing was
when I sat down with my accountant David
untracked and went over my tax return
for one of those years and I was like
but David why am I paying all this tax I
haven't had that much income this year
and he was like well you have this
income here is is short-term capital
gains and you have these expenses here
that you can't deduct from your income
because it's these miscellaneous
itemized deductions and it was like this
epiphany of gez what am I doing I've got
to go back to basics I've got to invest
in index funds I started to move the
ship towards indexing and immediately a
bunch of questions came up okay well I'm
going to invest in index funds how much
should I put in stocks versus bonds how
much should I have in non- US equities
versus US equities how do I think about
these different things they weren't such
difficult questions but they were
questions that needed answers and as I
thought about these things I was kind of
informed by experiences that I had had
up until then which some of the seminal
experiences and thinking about equities
for me was being in Japan in the late
80s working for Solomon Brothers and
just being there in the middle of this
crazy runup in valuations and Japanese
equities were trading at pees of a 100
for the whole broad market and yet
people were saying no worries they're
going to keep going higher and I think
that Japanese equities represented close
to 50% of global market cap so I kind of
felt like I wanted to have some guard
rails and some monitoring of my index
investing I didn't want to just say boom
I'm just going to be totally passive
market cap indexing and that's it and
never change anything and just take the
market caps because I kind of felt like
sometimes it really pays to have your
eyes open and be thinking about
long-term returns Not only was this
whole late 80s in Japan but then like
another decade or more later I'm sitting
there and just seeing this whole
internet bubble going on and 99 2000 and
again now I'm in 2006 and I'm looking
back on that and saying geez again I
love the idea of indexing lowc cost
diversification tax efficiency but if
I'm sitting in 200201 I want to be kind
of responding to that I mean that was a
time when tips were yielding 4%
long-term us tips and us and non- US
Equity markets were trading at pees of
25 or higher or earnings yields of 4% or
lower and I would have wanted to not
have that many equities back then these
ideas really informed how I wanted to
invest in index funds So eventually a
name for this approach to investing came
my way Dynamic index investing and then
as I was talking to friends and former
colleagues Etc about what I was doing
with my wealth people started to show
interest and say well if you did that
really professionally and properly we'd
like you to manage some of our money and
so the idea to set up Elm wealth was
born there was nobody offering anything
like it and I thought the things that we
could control fees taxes diversification
were all this lwh hanging fruit that I
needed to pick and to share so we set up
the firm in 2011 I set fees at 12 basis
points per year as the only fee which I
thought was appropriate if you're going
to invest in index funds you shouldn't
charge a high fee for helping people to
do that and the asset allocation that we
were coming up with was based on
publicly available research that lots of
people had done and just felt like okay
full transparency low fees tax
efficiency let's go and that became the
start of Elm in 2011 thinking of the
timeline here a lot of people take for
granted today the proliferation of
exchange traded funds but 2011 was still
early days the first funds were launched
in the early 90s depending on which
historian you talk to but it was really
post 2008 that ETFs exploded in
popularity how much of what you're able
to do today is actually predicated on
the emergence of
ETFs what we do today we could not have
done 20 years ago so first of all 20
years ago the only really lowcost index
funds in ETFs were primarily for us
equities I mean there were some
International Equity index funds that
Vanguard had but they were still fairly
expensive and lots of other asset
classes there were not lowcost index
funds I remember back in the '90s
wanting to get some high yield exposure
and there were no high yield index funds
at all there were no mun index funds at
all back then if I recall so that's one
aspect of it but the other aspect is
just the transactions costs custody fees
all of that were so high 15 years ago if
you wanted to do a separately managed
account at Fidelity the commissions on
doing trades could be as much as $25 a
trade then by the time we got started
doing separately managed Accounts at Elm
commissions on ETFs were down to $5 a
trade and then eventually went to zero
after Robin Hood turned up the
technology the Outsourcing everything
has come together to make what we do
today possible but it wasn't possible to
do it 15 years ago so before we dive
into the details I want to start sort of
at a 30,000 foot view of the strategy
that you have ended up implementing
today at Elm this Dynamic asset
allocation process can you talk a little
bit about the philosophies behind the
process without getting into those
nitty-gritty details and how those
philosophies end up translating into
maybe a top level portfolio view of what
you're trying to accomplish the best way
to describe what we do is imagine that
we live in a world which the academics
love to use this world we live in a
world where there's one risky asset call
it the global Equity Market or the
global market portfolio of risky assets
and there's one asset call it tips or
call it whatever you want treasury bills
some safe asset and you're trying to
decide how much of your savings you want
to put in the risky asset that's the
only choice you have you have a choice
of the safe asset or the risky asset and
you want to decide how much should I put
in there the amount that you should put
in there has to be a function of three
things it has to be a function of how
attractive it is what is the expected
return of this risky asset relative to
the safe asset it has to be a function
of how risky is the risky asset relative
to the safe asset and it has to be a
function of your personal degree of risk
aversion there's no other way to make
that decision or no other way that I can
think of to make that decision that's at
all rational or sensible risk aversion
is something that locally should stay
pretty constant over time there's not
reasons why our personal preferences
with regard to risk aversion arises from
the decreasing marginal utility of
wealth it should be relatively stable
through time and over some range of
wealth levels and so what it comes down
to is that your asset allocation how
much you allocate to the risky asset
should be a function of expected return
relative to the safe asset of the risky
asset and the risky assets risk and
that's what we do we just say okay we
have clients and we say to the client
let's try to figure out your degree of
risk aversion and we'll talk about that
in a bit and once we have that we say
okay we're going to come up with an
estimate of the long-term expected
return of equities relative to the safe
asset this is something that every large
investment firm has their expectations
for returns of equities and you can just
look it up online or you could go to our
website we publish our Capital Market
assumptions too but Vanguard Black Rock
Morgan Stanley everybody has their
Capital Market assumptions and to a
large extent they're bunched together
for long-term return expectations the
riskiness of the market there's lots of
ways of looking at that we can when
we're in early 2020 it was pretty risky
and uncertain other times the market is
very docile and peaceful and it's really
easy to observe that that should drive
your asset allocation really can't see
what's a really good rational
alternative to that I think that there's
other things that you can do if you
don't have the time or the inclination
or the ability to incorporate expected
returns and risk into your acid
allocation but I don't know of a sound
approach to investing than that so you
mentioned these three critical elements
you have to measure one of which is
going to be very client Centric and I
know from our prior discussions that you
have a set of onboarding questions you
need to ask clients before you can
calibrate this Dynamic process to their
wants and needs so let's start with
those onboarding questions what are you
asking clients and why do you see this
as such an important part of your
process the first question that we ask
clients is we say to them we're going to
manage some of your savings please tell
us how much of your account you would
like to have invested in equities in a
hypothetical World in which we agree
that equities have an expected return of
4% above the safe asset return and that
Equity risk is kind of in the middle
we're not at a very elevated level we're
not at a very quiet level of equity
Market volatility and uncertainty tell
us how much equities you want in your
account in that hypothetical world so
that's setting a baseline exposure to
equities in this 4% expected return
world that's the most important question
that we ask them in some sense that's
really asking two questions bunched into
one in that case we're asking them a
question of what's their risk aversion
and we're also asking them what do they
think is normal Equity Market risk so
we're combining those two things
together because we could try to
calibrate their risk aversion separately
but then we'd have to really make them
think about what risk level do we mean
and do they mean by normal Equity Market
risk and when people answer that
question our clients really Bunch
together we have over 400 clients
individuals and families and people
answer that question they say you know
I'd like to have between 50 and 100%
inequities in that case each client has
a different number but in general
clients kind of think that 4% expected
returns normal Equity risk yeah I'd like
to have 75% in equities in that case or
some other client is maybe younger or
more risk tolerant says I want to have
100% somebody else is like I want to
have 55% we don't get too many people
that want less than 50% if we sort of
tie it back to some classical Finance
formulas like the merens share it kind
of all ties out really nicely to a level
of risk aversion that we think typifies
most thoughtful investors out there so
we've also tried to calibrate risk
aversion directly by asking people
questions about gambles such as imagine
that you're flipping a coin and you're
going to bet some of your wealth on it
and it's a fair coin and if it comes up
Tails you're going to lose 20% of your
wealth and if it comes up heads you're
going to increase your wealth by 35% how
do you feel about that is that something
you really like is that something you
don't like is is that something you're
indifferent to and we can ask a bunch of
questions like that to also calibrate
risk aversion we did a survey like that
and wrote about it a few years ago and
we found that from over 100 people that
took that survey people really bunched
together I'm sure a lot of your
listeners are familiar with the Kelly
Criterion which is like a good way of
thinking about risk aversion what we
found was that this broad range of over
100 investors had risk aversion that
would be two to three times as risk
averse as the risk aversion that a Kelly
better or Kelly investor would have so
let's get into the portfolio
construction process itself you
calibrate to an Investor's preferences
and then you need to start running this
weekly Dynamic process you talked a
little bit about needing expected
returns and risk measures how are you
actually capturing those expected
returns and risk measures how are those
inputs that you're capturing translating
into Target weights so there's a lot of
consensus on what is the long-term
expected return of a big broad stock
market the US market or all non us
Equity markets even the global market
for that matter the strongest consensus
among Market observers and researchers
is that the earnings yield the
cyclically adjusted earnings yield of a
broad stock market is a decent simple
and one of the best estimates of the
long-term expected real return of that
Equity market so by the cyclically
adjusted earnings yield what we mean is
take the last 10 years of earnings
adjusted for inflation average it
together and divided by today's index
price the price of the stock market and
that's your earnings yield and you know
it makes some sense I mean there's
assumptions that are built into that the
Assumption that's the way to think about
it is that all of these companies are
like a big machine and they're producing
earnings from this big machine and the
earnings are coming out and if the
companies paid out all of their earnings
as dividends that these machines would
still be able to produce the same amount
of profit year after year adjusted for
inflation and that's kind of a really
simple and turns out you know
empirically a reasonable model for how
Corporate earnings work now in practice
especially in the US these days
companies don't pay out all of their
earnings as dividends they never really
have even going back a century but
payout ratios used to be higher and so
since companies retain some of their
earnings you expect their earnings to
grow a little faster because they're
investing some of the retained earnings
or they're investing all of the retained
earnings in trying to increase capacity
that modeling of earnings is both well
simple it's reasonable and it is not
refuted by history so I wouldn't say
that okay we look at history and it says
yeah this is what things look like and
so we say great but here's this model
and we look at it historically and it
actually fits history pretty well also
so that's the expected long-term real
return of equities this adjustment for
retained earnings is something that we
do at Elm we've written about it
Schiller and Campbell that gave us the
Campbell Schiller Cape number they
wanted to keep things really simple and
they wanted to use Cape more as a
regression variable rather than using
earnings yield as just a pure straight
up predictor of long-term expected
returns so we make this adjustment for
payout ratios and that bumps up earnings
yield a little bit for all the different
markets and so that's what we use we're
using that as a predictor of the
long-term real arithmetic return the
average annual return not the compound
return so when we compare it to what
other people are forecasting like if we
go to vanguards website and type in
Vanguard Capital Market assumptions and
see that they're giving a number for US
equities over the next 10 years of say
four and a half percent their number is
number one it's nominal our expected
return is real number so we have to make
an adjustment for inflation to see how
close we are to each other and then our
number is arithmetic and there's the
geometric so we need to make an
adjustment for a 10-year geometric
compound return versus a 10year
arithmetic return and when we do that we
actually find that if you look at four
or five of these places Vanguard Black
Rock Etc and maybe you throw out GMO who
thinks us equities are going to have a
negative return because they have a mean
reversion and a multiple built-in like
you throw out highs and lows and go with
the people in the middle you'll notice
that at least today the average is more
or less centered on this earnings yield
number for the broad market so that's
our long-term expected real return for
Equity so we have to compare it to a
long-term real return for a safe asset
and the long-term real return for a safe
asset the best place to look is the
yield on tips so we subtract one from
the other and that gives us what we
could call the risk premium and we're
going to compare that to 4% which is our
Baseline number that I was talking about
earlier and we're going to overweight or
underweight the equity Market or the
equity exposure for our client
proportionally to that which again is
the simp simple and sensible way to do
that that's the thing that's kind of
stable over time it doesn't move around
that much it does move around but it
doesn't move around that much that
quickly and then the riskiness of the
market is more volatile I mean risk is
more volatile than return as we know
especially short-term risk and so for
risk we could have and we thought about
it at the time just look at risk
directly look at the VIX Index look at
short-term options or slightly longer
term Equity options and look at the
implied volatility or do some blend
between implied volatility and realized
historic volatility we thought that
there were some challenges in doing that
I think we could have done that that
would have been a reasonable thing to do
instead we decided to use another metric
which is collinear with volatility we
decided to use a momentum metric so
comparing today's index level to a
one-year moving average adjusted for
inflation and risk premium or Total
return and risk premium using momentum
is like a good state in proxy for
measuring risk more directly and it has
some benefits it's super simple you can
set it up so like half the time you're
in a more risky State and half the time
it's positive half the time it's
negative on average with choosing to use
risk directly we would have to come up
with what do we think is the centering
point for that also if we were using
risk directly we'd really have a lot of
turnover because using realized and
implied volatility without smoothing it
in some way volatility is just very
volatile and so we would be generating a
lot of turnover if we were tracking that
so we would wind up doing some
postprocessing on it and by that time
now we have a measure that our investors
would be like okay this kind of feels a
little black boxy to me so we thought
momentum is nice and solid it's
coincident with the direct risk measure
if you go back historically and look at
times when momentum is positive Market
volatility is more subdued and vice
versa so we use momentum as a proxy for
risk when momentum is positive we deem
that a low risk environment we increase
exposures by a third basically to the
equity market and vice versa when
momentum is negative that tends to be a
higher risk environment where we
decrease client exposure to equities so
that's how we're doing it and we're
looking at every client's portfolio
every client's account on a weekly basis
and we're moving them towards these
targets that we have that come from
those metrics it's all very transparent
people can see the asset allocation
Targets on the website we have to manage
everybody's account especially taxable
accounts taking into consideration tax
effects from the rebalancing that we're
doing we don't want to have too much
turnover in people's accounts people
don't like that and we don't like that
so we're sort of targeting people to a
four-week moving average there's other
little implementation details but it's
all fully transparent in terms of how we
do it I want to push in on some of these
metrics a little bit and get your
detailed thoughts because there are
critiques to things like cape or
cyclically adjusted earnings yield
particularly when you're talking either
measuring it on a Time series basis or
looking at it cross-sectionally across
different regions there's arguments that
it doesn't really adequately account for
things like differences in Industry
composition or changes in profit margins
over time how would you address these
critiques in your use of C or cyclically
adjusted earnings yield the first thing
I would say is that Simplicity is a
merit and so I think the benefit of
Simplicity has to be weighed against
perhaps a better estimate with a more
complex estimate that takes more things
into account and trying to find that
balance is important with complexity
you're always going to have to guard
against a backfit bias you have to
realize you're never going to get the
expected return you're always going to
get something that's higher or lower
than that you don't want to get into to
a raise to the bottom in terms of just
fitting what we've just seen behind us
now in terms of those specific critiques
a lot of people say look us equities are
trading at twice the multiple or half
the earnings yield of the rest of the
world but that's just because the US has
so much Tech and the rest of the world
doesn't well actually you could really
do that analysis we've done it we've
published about it it's really straight
forward and if you would make the whole
world have the same industry
compositions so take the whole world's
industry composition average and now say
imagine that the US has the same
industry composition as the whole world
and the non- US market also has the same
industry composition as the whole world
that makes a small difference to
earnings yield in PE but not much if the
earnings yield of us equities is just
over 3% and the rest of the world is
just over 6% so call it a 3% difference
this industry composition represents
about 50 BAS points of that so about one
sixth of the difference I can't speak
that much about profit margins but
obviously businesses change over time
and first of all accounting metrics
change over time so when we're looking
at how Gap accounting worked in the
1960s or 1980s or today or how
accounting metrics are going to be
reported 20 years from now they're
definitely moving but again from a
Simplicity point of view we think they
have't mve all that much and that in the
end some of these things turn out to be
timing differences Etc and so there's a
ton of things that you can criticize
about how earnings are calculated and
using it but we try to think about these
we read about them at the end of the day
when we think about this balance between
Simplicity and not making our metrics be
return chasing metrics we just have said
we'd rather just keep something simple
and stable Through Time rather than
making a lot of modifications to it a
lot of the criticisms are fair but I
think that at the same time this Cally
adjusted earnings yield is the single
best metric that is out there people are
saying oh you know what I'm going to do
is I'm going to use forecasted earnings
and combine that with historical
earnings and that will be like a blended
number that's good I mean you have a
problem there that it's a little bit
harder to use that historically because
we didn't have good earnings forecasts
going further back but I think that's a
reasonable
thing to do when you do that it doesn't
change things that much overall I think
earnings yields points in the right
direction I mean I just think that
whatever adjustments you make I just
don't think you can say that us equities
has a 6% earnings yield I just don't
think there's any way of coming up with
us equities has a 6% long-term return
above inflation when the earnings yield
is at 3% I don't think it's that wrong
whatever you do it's going to be around
3% and a lot of people have published
stuff about that what would we need for
us equities to return 10% over the next
10 years the only reasonable way to get
that would be multiple expansion I mean
it's just not that reasonable
historically we've had all of these
massive Revolutions in technology
productivity Etc and we just never see
earnings do what they would need to do
to justify to be consistent with today's
earnings yields indicating 8% real
returns for us equities you mentioned
using tips as the basis for measuring
real returns and two questions come up
there I'm sure there will be listeners
who would critique the idea of using CPI
as a measure of inflation so that's one
side of it but the other that comes to
mind for me as someone who's run Dynamic
processes like this is tips tend to have
a liquidity issue in a crisis and so I
could see that you could end up with
potentially very highly skewed or
incorrect measur of your inflation
adjusted earnings yield precisely in
those periods where you would expect the
portfolio to be the most dynamic how do
you think about those problems so first
of all let's agree that if you're going
to use earnings yield that earnings
yield is an estimate of the long-term
real return of equities so we have to
compare it against the real return of a
safe asset if we think that the yield on
tips is wrong at some point in some
sense I think that's what you're saying
that they could be trading at 3% but
that's a bad signal they're really at 2%
well the thing is that you can buy tips
if I wake up one day and US equities has
an earnings yield of 3% and I can buy
30-year tips at 4% and I say you know
what these tips all these relative value
players had to sell them they should
really be at 2% but somehow they're at
4% well I don't care I'm just going to
buy them so they're relevant even though
I do agree that they tend to trade cheap
I think that they are a real thing that
you can buy from that point of view even
to the extent that they suffer from
maybe not being the best estimates of
the real return they're a tradable
estimate of the real return and so I
think that means that it makes sense in
terms of CPI again we're just trying to
compare like for like we're thinking
about a return estimate for us equities
as thinking about it relative to CPI so
we just want to measure Apples to Apples
when we're thinking about risk premium
so even if CPI is not a great measure
like if CPI is is maybe under
representing inflation we're getting
that on both sides of the comparison if
we think about Equity returns relative
to CPI as well when we talk about Market
risk there are maybe three big drivers
that tend to come up changes in discount
rates changes in earning expectations
and then maybe generic investor
sentiment I want to focus sort of on the
first two as being fundamental drivers
of risk I'm curious as to your thoughts
how much of Market risk do you think
comes from changes in discount rates
versus how much a market risk comes from
changes in earnings expectations and how
does this influence your choice of using
cyclically adjusted earnings yield and
long-term momentum as your primary
variables this idea that the equity
Market is more volatile than you would
get from just changes in earnings
expectations or earnings realizations
this goes back to the seminal paper by
Bob Schiller that's probably one of the
top papers of his and contributions that
led to his Nobel Prize what Schiller did
